L1_summary_of_paper: Danneels (2012) theorizes and tests how firms’ second-order competences—capabilities to create new resources—translate into profitability via a Schumpeterian competition process, contingent on competitive turbulence. He distinguishes second-order marketing competence (ability to add new market-related resources and customer competences) and second-order R&D competence (ability to add new technological resources and technological competences), arguing these dynamic capabilities generate Schumpeterian rents (rents from resource flow/renewal) rather than Ricardian rents (from existing resource stocks). Using multiple-informant surveys in 2007 for U.S. public manufacturing firms and archival ROA (2007–2009) from Compustat, he tests that competitive turbulence negatively moderates the marketing-competence → ROA link and positively moderates the R&D-competence → ROA link. Results support both: marketing competence predicts ROA under low/moderate turbulence but not under high turbulence; R&D competence predicts ROA only when turbulence is high. This links dynamic capabilities to performance through a competitive-process lens and clarifies environmental contingencies in capability value, while providing operational measures of second-order competences.
A1_citation: Danneels, E. (2012). Second-order competences and Schumpeterian rents. Strategic Entrepreneurship Journal, 6(1), 42–58.
C3_metric_detail: Competitive turbulence captured as perceived rate of entry, exit, and strategy change among competitors, using a 5-item Likert scale (α≈0.72).
D2_key_assumptions_addressed: Temporal precedence via lagged dependent variable (ROA 2002)
Controls for first-order competences, firm size, age, and industries
Measurement validity (factor structure, reliability, interrater checks)
D2_robustness_suite: Other: Measurement validation and interrater reliability
Other: Multicollinearity checks and respondent-type controls
E3_mechanisms_tags: Other: Creative destruction via imitation/substitution barriers
F2_risk_of_bias_notes: Perceptual capability measures may introduce measurement bias; mitigated by multiple informants, CFA, reliability, and discriminant validity checks. Causal inference limited without quasi-experimental design.
G1_construct_mapping_note: Second-order competences map to dynamic capabilities (resource flow) whereas first-order competences map to RBV (resource stock); competitive turbulence maps to environmental dynamism in competitive dynamics.
G4_unifying_props_drafts: P1: The profitability impact of second-order competences is conditional on competitive turbulence.
P2: Marketing-oriented second-order competences yield rents under low/moderate turbulence; R&D-oriented second-order competences yield rents under high turbulence.
P3: Dynamic capabilities generate Schumpeterian (flow-based) rents distinct from Ricardian (stock-based) rents.
I1_mechanism_statements: Second-order competences → creation of new resources/competences (flow) → capacity to imitate/substitute rivals’ resources → Schumpeterian rents in disequilibrium.
Market-related resources are observable and weakly protected; thus turbulence accelerates imitation, eroding rents from marketing competence.
Technological resources are less observable and better protected; thus turbulence amplifies the rent potential of R&D competence.

I2_mediation_moderation_details.role_in_link: Negatively moderates (Marketing second-order competence → ROA); slope strong at low turbulence, null at high turbulence.
Positively moderates (R&D second-order competence → ROA); slope significant only at high turbulence.

J1_main_findings_summary: Marketing second-order competence improves ROA under low/moderate turbulence but not under high turbulence.
R&D second-order competence improves ROA only when turbulence is high.
Findings hold controlling for first-order competences and lagged performance; multicollinearity and respondent-type checks show robustness.
Links dynamic capabilities to Schumpeterian rents by introducing competitive turbulence as a conditioning factor.
J2_finding_evidence_links: Table 3 (interaction terms and controls); Table 4 (simple slopes); Figure 1a–1b (plots of moderation).
K1_contribution_summary: The paper operationalizes second-order competences and shows their profitability effects depend on competitive turbulence, thereby connecting dynamic capabilities to Schumpeterian rents and specifying distinct contingencies for marketing versus R&D exploration.
